title: The ionic compound lithium (Z=3) reacts with oxygen (Z=8). If a sample contains 1.07×1022 lithium ions, how many oxide ions does it contain? - Quora

response.answer_text: The question is a little awkward…. Lithium is an element, not a compound. Being in the first column of the periodic table, it has one 2s electron that it would like to give away to get a valence of +1. Oxygen atoms are in column 6A, with 6 valence electrons, needing 2 to fill its 2s/2p shell, so it has a valence of -2. Lithium oxide, therefore will have 2 Li+ atoms and one O-2 atoms to have the same number of + and - charges….. Li2O. The balanced equation, given that oxygen is diatomic and comes in O2 molecules, is: 4Li + O2 → 2 Li2O The ratio of Li:O2 is 2:1. If your sample has 1.07 x 10^22 Li ions, there will half the number of O ions. Doing the math gives 0.535 x 10^22, and to make it prettier, move the decimal to the right; 5.35 x 10^21 O -2 ions.

Li ( Z=3 ) , E.C. 2,1 Lithium will lose one electron to form unipositive ions. O ( Z=8 ), E. C. 2, 6 Oxygen will gain 2 electrons to form binegative ion So formula of Lithium oxide will be Li2O Hence number of oxide ions will half the number of Lithium ions or 1.07 × 10^22 / 2 Or 0.585 × 10^22 ions.
